item.title: Maduro’s Gesture Was Not Just a Peace Sign
item.description: The captured authoritarian leader flashed a symbol that many took to be a defiant peace sign. Loyal lawmakers repeated the gesture at a session in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Adam Gray/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, arriving in New York, on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Machado Praises Trump in Fox News Interview
item.description: María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, offered to share her Nobel Peace Prize with President Trump. He has refused to back her.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a rally during the country’s presidential election in 2024.

item.title: Venezuela Braces for Economic Collapse From U.S. Blockade
item.description: Venezuela could lose the bulk of its export revenues this year if the U.S. blockade stays in place, according to internal government estimates, a scenario that would set off a humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees outside Venezuela’s state oil company, known as PDVSA, in Caracas in October.

item.title: Outside at Maduro’s Court Appearance: Flags, Chants and Venezuelans’ Quiet Pain
item.description: A demonstration outside the building where Nicolás Maduro was arraigned was a ritual of New York public protest, but one that sprang from personal wounds inflicted a continent away.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Bensimon and Maia Coleman
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters on Monday facing off across barricades in a park outside a federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Cuban Deaths in U.S. Venezuela Strikes Confirm Ties Between Countries
item.description: The Maduro regime was long propped up by Cuba’s armed forces and intelligence agencies. Many Cubans were reported killed in the American military action.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife, Cilia Flores, during a pro-government march last month in Caracas. Many of the bodyguards that protected Mr. Maduro were Cuban.

item.title: Venezuela’s Legislators Offer Scorn as Trump Demands Obedience
item.description: The convening of the National Assembly made it clear that Maduro loyalists remain entrenched across Venezuelan institutions after decades of purges and crackdowns on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, María Victoria Fermín and Annie Correal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Maduro demonstration near Parliament in Caracas on Monday.

item.title: The C.I.A. assessed Venezuela’s future without Maduro ahead of the U.S. operation.
item.description: The assessment aided President Trump and other officials in concluding that Delcy Rodríguez, then Venezuela’s vice president, was Nicolás Maduro’s best short-term successor, according to people briefed on the matter.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s vice president, was sworn in as interim leader on Monday, two days after the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, was captured in a U.S. military raid.

item.title: Why Trump Refused to Back Venezuela’s Machado: Fears of Chaos, and Fraying Ties
item.description: U.S. intelligence suggested María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, would struggle to lead the government. But her relationship with Trump officials had been souring for months.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado and her surrogate presidential candidate, Edmundo González, at a rally in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, in 2024.

item.title: Venezuela Detained and Deported Members of the Foreign Press
item.description: Military officers detained 14 members of the news media during a National Assembly session. All were released after their phones were searched. One was deported.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators walking toward the National Assembly during a march in Venezuela’s capital, Caracas, as the new National Assembly began on Monday.

item.title: A Revival of Venezuela’s Oil Industry Poses a Challenge for Canada
item.description: The two countries both produce heavy oil, which is difficult to refine, and have relied historically on American refineries to buy it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Historically Canada and Venezuela were direct competitors in the oil business.

item.title: Maduro Laywer Is Barry Pollack, Who Also Defended Assange
item.description: Mr. Pollack has also represented Julian Assange and an official of Enron.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barry Pollack, second from right, has long experience negotiating with the federal government.

item.title: Maduro Says He Is a Prisoner of War, Not a Defendant. The Words Matter.
item.description: His simple statement in federal court was aimed directly at contradictions in the Trump administration’s actions in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal District Court building in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Russia Once Offered U.S. Control of Venezuela for Free Rein in Ukraine
item.description: The exchange offer was recounted at the time in congressional testimony by Fiona Hill, who ran Russian and European affairs on the National Security Council during the first Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2019, Fiona Hill told a Congressional hearing that the Russians “were signaling very strongly that they wanted to somehow make some very strange swap arrangement between Venezuela and Ukraine.”

item.title: Chevron’s Risky Bet to Stay in Venezuela May Now Give It an Advantage
item.description: The second-largest U.S. oil company, which kept pumping oil in the country after others left, could find it relatively easy to expand its operations if the political conditions there improve.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in El Palito, Venezuela. Chevron is the only U.S. oil company with federal authorization to export oil from Venezuela.

item.title: At the U.N., Even Allies Condemn U.S. Action in Venezuela
item.description: The deputy French U.N. ambassador said it chipped “away at the very foundation of international order.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the U.N. Security Council on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Taps High-Profile Canadian Politician as Economic Adviser
item.description: Ukraine’s president appointed Chrystia Freeland, a former deputy prime minister of Canada, to a role in which she would advise on postwar reconstruction, if peace talks are successful.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chrystia Freeland during an interview last year in Toronto.

item.title: Congress Is Divided Over Maduro Raid After First Briefing
item.description: The classified session for congressional leaders and the top members of the intelligence, defense and foreign policy panels came two days after the military operation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration left lawmakers in the dark about the raid in Venezuela, a decision that President Trump has said was made out of concern that they would leak details of the operation before it was carried out.

item.title: Maduro, Appearing in U.S. Court for Arraignment, Says He Was ‘Kidnapped’ and Pleads Not Guilty
item.description: “I’m innocent. I’m not guilty. I am a decent man,” the captured Venezuelan president told a judge in Manhattan federal court. “I am still president of my country.”
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, Benjamin Weiser, Maia Coleman and Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, the ousted leader of Venezuela, at the Downtown Manhattan Heliport before being taken to the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Caribbean Travelers Are Stranded After U.S. Raid in Venezuela Cancels Flights
item.description: Mass flight cancellations during peak holiday travel season have forced travelers to miss school and work and to spend thousands on extended tropical vacations.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Travelers were stuck at airports like Luis Muñoz Marín International near San Juan, P.R., after the United States closed some Caribbean airspace on Saturday during a raid to capture the president of Venezuela.

item.title: James Luckey-Lange, American Detained in Venezuela, Is Being Held by Country’s Counterintelligence
item.description: The location of James Luckey-Lange of New York City, who went missing in Venezuela in early December, was previously unknown.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: Why Trump Wants Greenland
item.description: President Trump has reiterated his interest in annexing Denmark’s semiautonomous territory, saying it is vital for America’s national security.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: Nuuk, the capital city of Greenland, in March. Polls show that a vast majority of the island’s population do not support being taken over by the United States.

item.title: Who Is Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s New Interim President After Maduro’s Capture?
item.description: Ms. Rodríguez, who is leading Venezuela after the U.S. captured Nicolás Maduro, established a reputation as a shrewd operator guiding the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins and Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez in Caracas, Venezuela, in September.

item.title: Trump’s Threat of Force Against Colombia Draws Rebuke From Its Leader
item.description: President Gustavo Petro said that he had asked the Colombian people to defend him “against any illegitimate violent act.” His defense minister emphasized that security cooperation with Washington continued.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Sergio Yate/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia said he “asked the people to defend the president against any illegitimate violent act.”

item.title: Denmark’s Leader Says Trump ‘Should Be Taken Seriously’ on Greenland
item.description: The Danish prime minister’s comments on Monday came a day after she told President Trump to “stop the threats” against the semiautonomous Danish territory following the U.S. military raid in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark said that the United States had “no right to annex” Greenland and that the island was not for sale.

item.title: After Venezuela, Trump Says Cuba Is ‘Ready to Fall’
item.description: The capture of Nicolás Maduro is a devastating blow to the alliance between Venezuela and Cuba. Many wonder if the island nation will be targeted next.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
item.media:credit: Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press
item.media:description: People rally in solidarity with Venezuela in Havana, Cuba, after the United States captured Nicolas Maduro on Saturday.

item.title: After Venezuela, Trump Offers Hints About What Could Be Next
item.description: President Trump’s comments about Greenland, Colombia and Cuba offered a glimpse of how emboldened he feels after the quick capture of Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser, Jonah E. Bromwich, Hurubie Meko and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: Sanctioned Oil Tankers Flee Venezuela in Defiance of U.S. Blockade
item.description: The ships are using deceptive tactics as part of a seemingly coordinated attempt to bypass American naval forces in the region.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump Says ‘We Need Greenland’ and Threatens U.S. Action in Colombia and Mexico
item.description: In remarks aboard Air Force One, President Trump threatened Colombia and its president, described Cuba as “ready to fall” and reasserted his desire to acquire Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked on Air Force One on Sunday whether his administration would target Colombia, President Trump replied, “It sounds good to me.”

item.title: Cuba Says 32 of Its Citizens Died in Venezuela, Including Military Personnel
item.description: President Miguel Díaz-Canel said the casualties were from Cuba’s armed forces or interior ministry. The country is a longstanding ally of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Antennas hit by U.S. airstrikes in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Calls for Dialogue and ‘Coexistence’ With U.S.
item.description: Acting President Delcy Rodríguez struck a more diplomatic tone than she had on Saturday, inviting the United States to “work together on a cooperative agenda.”
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Leonardo Fernandez Viloria/Reuters
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, now Venezuela’s acting president, in Caracas last year.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s New Leader, Faces Big Test
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez is the torchbearer of a government whose revolutionary roots are in disarray. She must appease constituencies who loathe U.S. meddling while fielding Washington’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Isayen Herrera and María Victoria Fermín
item.media:credit: Gaby Oraa/Reuters
item.media:description: A photo of Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, from August. With her were Foreign Minister Yvan Gil, left, and a Venezuelan lawyer, Larry Devoe.

item.title: Iran and Venezuela found kinship in anti-American ideology and in evading U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ebrahim Raisi, left, and Nicolás Maduro delivering a joint statement at Miraflores Presidential Palace in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2023 when they were the leaders of Iran and Venezuela.

item.title: What Latin America Thinks of Trump’s Goal to Dominate It
item.description: President Trump has launched a new era of U.S. intervention in Latin America. Some regional leaders are celebrating, while many others are deeply concerned.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Jesus Linares, 48, and Reggie Carrero, 52, in a damaged apartment on Sunday in Catia La Mar, Venezuela, after strikes conducted by the U.S. military as part of the operation to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Exiled Venezuelans Celebrate Maduro’s Downfall, but Are Wary
item.description: “I had utterly lost hope,” said one Venezuelan who has lived in exile from his country for seven years.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelans took to the streets of Cúcuta, Colombia, to celebrate on Saturday.

item.title: Satellite Imagery Reveals Damage to Venezuelan Base Where Maduro Was Captured
item.description: Before-and-after imagery released on Sunday shows that at least five buildings at the complex were destroyed by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Behind the Scenes of Our Nicolás Maduro Front Page
item.description: After President Trump’s surprise ouster of Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, a team of New York Times editors set to work redoing the front page.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ‘They’re Invading Us’: The U.S. Attack Viewed From Venezuelans’ Cellphones
item.description: The videos, filmed on cellphones by people mainly in Caracas and La Guaira, showed the exact moments in which the U.S. air and ground incursion played out in real time.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Arijeta Lajka and McKinnon de Kuyper
item.media:credit: via Reuters

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Is ‘In Charge’ of Venezuela, While Rubio Stresses Coercing It
item.description: The secretary of state said that a military “quarantine” on some oil exports would stay in place to put pressure on the country’s acting leadership.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at a news conference with President Trump at Mar-a-Lago, the president’s private estate and club in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday morning.

item.title: U.S. Has No Troops in Venezuela, Defense Department Says
item.description: A significant buildup of U.S. soldiers and ships will remain in the Caribbean and surrounding countries to protect “our interests the region,” the Joint Chiefs chairman said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump suggested there would be a “second wave” of military action in Venezuela if the United States ran into resistance.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Jack Nicas, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Trump Fixed On a Maduro Loyalist as Venezuela’s New Leader
item.description: Nicolás Maduro balked at a gilded exile. U.S. officials then saw a more pliant option in his vice president, Delcy Rodríguez, known for stabilizing Venezuela’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Tyler Pager, Simon Romero and Julie Turkewitz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, now the country’s interim leader, speaking at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 2019.

item.title: Why Trump Removed Venezuela’s Maduro
item.description: David E. Sanger, our national security correspondent, describes the implications of President Trump’s launching of the attack that captured the Venezuelan president, and Trump’s declaration that the United States would “run the country.”
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Leila Medina and June Kim

item.title: After U.S. Attack, Venezuelans Worry About Political Stability
item.description: Nicolás Maduro was unpopular. But his abrupt removal has created deep uncertainty, alarming even those who opposed him.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Frances Robles
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: In Caracas, the streets were silent on Saturday, save for a few small demonstrations organized by the government to protest Nicolás Maduro’s ouster.
